text: In my best year at Uber, I made about 320 or $330,000 in total compensation. And when I quit my job, I was actually thinking, am I crazy? Because I am leaving... Especially in Europe, this is a lot of money. But now I am making more in compensation that I made at Uber. And the difference is that now my compensation... Well, my earnings keep going up as long as the newsletter is growing, so there's no theoretical cap on this.
speaker: Gergely Orosz
context: Lenny asks Gergely to compare his income from running a paid newsletter versus his previous high-paying tech job at Uber. Gergely explains that he left a very lucrative position in Europe (around $330,000 annually) to pursue newsletter writing full-time, initially expecting to make much less money. He shares how his current newsletter income has surprisingly exceeded his Uber compensation, with the key difference being that newsletter earnings can theoretically grow indefinitely as long as subscriber numbers increase, unlike fixed corporate salaries.
text_ko: 우버에서 가장 잘 벌었던 해에 총보수(total compensation)가 대략 32만~33만 달러였어요. 회사를 그만둘 때는 솔직히 '내가 미친 건가?'라는 생각도 했어요. 떠나는 거였으니까요... 특히 유럽에선 정말 큰돈이잖아요. 그런데 지금은 우버 때보다 보수(compensation)를 더 받고 있어요. 차이라면 지금 제 수입은 뉴스레터(newsletter)가 성장하는 한 계속 늘어나서 이론적으로 상한선이 없다는 점이에요.
text_zh: 我在Uber最好的那年，总收入大概是32万到33万美金。当时辞职的时候，我真的在想，我是不是疯了？因为我要放弃这份工作...特别是在欧洲，这可是一大笔钱啊。但是现在我的收入已经超过了在Uber的时候。区别就在于，现在我的收入...怎么说呢，只要我的邮件订阅(newsletter)一直在增长，我的收入就会一直涨，理论上没有天花板。
text_es: En mi mejor año en Uber, gané como 320 o 330 mil dólares en compensación total. Y cuando renuncié, de verdad pensé: ¿estaré loco? Porque estaba dejando... Sobre todo en Europa, esa es muchísima plata. Pero ahora estoy ganando más de lo que ganaba en Uber. Y la diferencia es que ahora mi compensación... Bueno, mis ingresos siguen subiendo mientras el newsletter siga creciendo, así que no hay un tope teórico en esto.

text: So I was working on parallel things at the same time, and I was often running against the deadline, I was barely finishing it, which is not what I was expecting initially. The first few months I feel was a bit more stressed, but again, the good thing is I cleared my calendar, so I said I'm not talking with anyone, I'm just doing this.
speaker: Gergely Orosz
context: Lenny asks about what daily life is like running a newsletter full-time, since people might think writing one post per week sounds easy. Gergely explains that creating quality newsletter content actually takes much more time than expected - requiring research, writing, feedback, and editing phases that can span an entire week. He describes how the first few months were surprisingly stressful as he learned to manage multiple projects simultaneously while working against weekly publishing deadlines.
text_ko: 그래서 저는 여러 일을 동시에 병행하고 있었고, 마감(deadline)에 자주 쫓겨 거의 간신히 마무리하곤 했어요. 처음에는 그렇게 될 줄 몰랐어요. 첫 몇 달은 스트레스를 좀 많이 받았던 것 같아요. 그래도 다행인 건 일정을 비워둬서 누구랑도 얘기하지 않고 이 일에만 집중하기로 했다는 점이에요.
text_zh: 所以我当时同时在做好几个项目，经常赶deadline，基本上都是卡着点儿完成，这跟我最初的预期完全不一样。头几个月压力确实挺大的，不过好在我把日程全清空了，跟谁都不见，就专心做这一件事。
text_es: Entonces estaba trabajando en varias cosas a la vez, y siempre andaba corriendo contra el tiempo, apenas lograba terminar, lo cual no era para nada lo que esperaba al principio. Los primeros meses sí me sentí bastante estresado, pero bueno, lo bueno es que liberé mi agenda completamente, o sea dije "no voy a hablar con nadie, solo me voy a enfocar en esto."

text: Without that, when you're on your own, when you're entrepreneur, I was a great... I think I was a really diligent employee. I always tried to get my work done, show up on time, I tried to meet all expectations. But what I noticed is, when I started to work for myself, it just went out the window. Almost 15 years of being this star employee who really wants to do well, I found myself upset at myself for not... Just wasting my day.
speaker: Gergely Orosz
context: Gergely and Lenny are discussing the challenges of self-directed work and staying productive without external structure. Gergely shares a surprising discovery about the transition from corporate employment to entrepreneurship - despite being an extremely disciplined and high-performing employee for 15 years, he found himself struggling with productivity and time management when working independently. This illustrates a common challenge entrepreneurs face when they lose the external accountability and structure that corporate environments provide.
text_ko: 그게 없으니까, 혼자일 때나 창업가로 일할 때는요... 저는 정말 성실한 직원이었어요. 항상 일을 끝내려고 했고, 제시간에 출근했고, 모든 기대를 맞추려고 노력했어요. 그런데 혼자 일하기 시작하니까 그런 것들이 싹 사라지더라고요. 거의 15년 동안 잘하려고 애쓴 모범 직원이었는데, 막상 혼자 일하니까 하루를 그냥 낭비하는 제 자신에게 화가 났어요.
text_zh: 没有这个的话，当你自己创业的时候，我以前是个很棒的...我觉得我真的是个特别勤奋的员工。我总是努力把工作做完，按时上班，尽量达到所有要求。但我发现，当我开始为自己工作的时候，这些习惯就全没了。做了将近15年的明星员工，真的很想把事情做好，结果我发现自己在为没有...就是在浪费时间而生自己的气。
text_es: Sin eso, cuando trabajas por tu cuenta, cuando eres emprendedor... yo era un... creo que era un empleado muy responsable. Siempre trataba de terminar mi trabajo, llegar puntual, cumplir con todas las expectativas. Pero lo que me di cuenta es que cuando empecé a trabajar para mí mismo, se me fue todo por la borda. Casi 15 años de ser ese empleado estrella que de verdad quería destacar, y me encontré molesto conmigo mismo por no... simplemente por desperdiciar el día.

text: I use Twitter for a lot of research. And unfortunately what that means is when I start to write something, it can really pull my attention, because I have Twitter open and then I get a message from someone. It's a little bit like Slack, but I'd argue it can be worse, because also Twitter for me is also something that is very useful in generating people raising awareness.
speaker: Gergely Orosz
context: Lenny asks Gergely about productivity challenges and how to stay focused while working independently. Gergely describes a specific dilemma many content creators face - Twitter serves a dual purpose as both a research tool and a marketing platform for his newsletter business, making it difficult to avoid distractions. Unlike typical workplace distractions, social media platforms create a complex situation where the distraction source is also legitimately part of the work, making it harder to simply block or avoid.
text_ko: 저는 트위터(Twitter)를 리서치할 때 많이 사용해요. 안타깝게도 그게 의미하는 건, 뭔가 글을 쓰기 시작하면 트위터를 켜둔 상태에서 누가 메시지를 보내면 금방 집중이 흐트러진다는 거예요. 약간 슬랙(Slack) 같기도 한데, 오히려 더 나쁠 수 있어요. 제게 트위터는 사람들의 관심을 환기시키고 인식을 높이는 데도 정말 유용하거든요.
text_zh: 我经常用推特做研究。但问题是，一旦我开始写东西的时候，注意力就特别容易被分散，因为推特一直开着，然后就有人给我发消息。这跟Slack有点像，但我觉得推特可能更糟糕，因为对我来说，推特还有个很重要的作用就是帮我提升知名度、扩大影响力。
text_es: Uso Twitter para hacer mucha investigación. Y desafortunadamente lo que pasa es que cuando me pongo a escribir algo, me distrae muchísimo, porque tengo Twitter abierto y de repente me llega un mensaje de alguien. Es un poco como Slack, pero yo diría que puede ser peor, porque además Twitter para mí también es muy útil para generar que la gente se entere de las cosas, para crear awareness.

text: And I was asking myself, all right, and then what? And I was like, after I've bought everything that I don't need, I probably want to share what I know with people, do YouTube videos and write books. And I was thinking to myself, so hold on. I would go off and do this for like ten years, because that's how much you need to plan to do it.
speaker: Gergely Orosz
context: Gergely explains his thought process when deciding between starting a traditional venture-funded startup versus pursuing newsletter writing. He was calculating the potential financial outcomes of building a unicorn startup, realizing that even after achieving massive success (like a billion-dollar valuation), his ultimate goal would be to share knowledge through content creation - exactly what he could do immediately. This realization led him to question why he should spend a decade building a company just to end up doing what he was already interested in doing.
text_ko: 그래서 저는 '좋아, 그다음엔?' 하고 제 자신에게 물었어요. 그리고 '필요 없는 걸 다 사고 나면 아마 아는 걸 사람들과 나누고, 유튜브 영상도 만들고 책도 쓰게 될 거예요'라고 생각했어요. 그러다가 '잠깐만, 이걸 하려면 한 10년은 해야겠더라고요' 하고 생각했어요. 그만큼 장기적으로 계획해야 하니까요.
text_zh: 然后我就在想，好吧，接下来呢？我想着，等我把那些用不着的东西都买完了，我可能就想跟大家分享一下我知道的东西，做做YouTube视频，写写书什么的。然后我又想，等等，这样的话我得花个十年时间去搞这个，因为你得提前规划这么长时间才行。
text_es: Y me estaba preguntando, bueno, ¿y después qué? Y pensé, después de comprarme todo lo que no necesito, probablemente voy a querer compartir lo que sé con la gente, hacer videos de YouTube y escribir libros. Y me dije, espera un momento. Me iría a hacer esto como por diez años, porque eso es lo que necesitas planificar para hacerlo bien.

text: So there was years of work, and I wish I could tell you how to build a successful newsletter, but the best advice I have is still what Jeff Atwood does, except I have less conviction. But if you start writing, and you do it regularly, two things will happen. First of all, you're going to you write for yourself and you keep improving, you'll be a better writer. That's for sure.
speaker: Gergely Orosz
context: Lenny asks how Gergely got his first thousand newsletter subscribers, expecting tactical advice. Gergely explains that his 'overnight success' was actually built on six years of consistent blogging and building an audience. He references advice from Jeff Atwood (Stack Overflow founder) about becoming internet-famous through consistent writing - publish regularly for an extended period. Gergely emphasizes that while he can't guarantee newsletter success, consistent writing practice will definitely improve your skills as a writer.
text_ko: 그건 수년간의 작업이었어요. 성공적인 뉴스레터(newsletter)를 어떻게 만드는지 확실히 알려드리고 싶지만, 제가 드릴 수 있는 가장 좋은 조언은 제프 앳우드(Jeff Atwood)가 하는 방식이에요. 다만 저는 그만큼 확신은 없어요. 그래도 글쓰기를 시작해서 꾸준히 하면 두 가지가 일어나요. 우선 스스로를 위해 글을 쓰게 되고, 계속해서 실력이 늘면서 확실히 더 나은 글쓴이가 돼요.
text_zh: 所以这是好几年的功夫，我真希望能告诉你怎么做出一个成功的newsletter，但我能给的最好建议还是学Jeff Atwood那套，只不过我没他那么有把握。不过如果你开始写，而且坚持定期写的话，会有两个效果。首先，你为自己而写，不断改进，你的文笔肯定会越来越好。这个是肯定的。
text_es: Fueron años de trabajo, y me encantaría poder decirte cómo crear un newsletter exitoso, pero el mejor consejo que tengo sigue siendo lo que hace Jeff Atwood, aunque yo lo tengo menos claro. Pero si empiezas a escribir y lo haces con regularidad, van a pasar dos cosas. Primero, vas a escribir para ti mismo y vas a ir mejorando, vas a ser mejor escritor. Eso te lo aseguro.
